action.action-desc: Mr. Reed (for himself and Mr. Murphy of Florida) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure

form.official-title: To provide assistance to communities affected by total maximum daily loads established by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, and for other purposes.

section.text:
This Act may be cited as the
Impaired Waters Improvement Act
.
In this Act, the following definitions apply:

paragraph.text:
The term Administrator means the
Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency
.

The term covered TMDL means a total maximum daily load for nitrogen, phosphorus, or sediment established under
section 303(d) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (
33 U.S.C. 1313(d)
).

subparagraph.text: The term covered TMDL jurisdiction means a geographic area that is subject to a covered TMDL.

The term covered TMDL jurisdiction includes the geographic area subject to total maximum daily load for pollutants for the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries established by the Administrator on December 29, 2010, and noticed at 76 Fed. Reg. 549 (January 5, 2011).

paragraph.text: The term publicly owned stormwater management practices means techniques for managing and treating rainwater runoff that are the responsibility of the public sector, including, and by order of preference, practices which—

subparagraph.text: utilize or mimic natural infiltration of rainwater into the ground;
hold and treat runoff by allowing plant materials to take up pollutants; and

capture runoff and hold it for a period of time sufficient to allow pollutants to settle out or evaporate, and which substantially reduce the volume of runoff in local waters during peak runoff periods.

paragraph.text:
The term treatment works has the meaning given the term in
section 212 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (
33 U.S.C. 1292
).

section.header: Grants to assist covered TMDL jurisdictions

subsection.text:
The
Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency
may make grants to the owner or operator of—

paragraph.text: a publicly owned treatment works serving a covered TMDL jurisdiction;
publicly owned storm water management practices serving a covered TMDL jurisdiction; or
a privately owned farm implementing methods to reduce discharges of nitrogen, phosphorus, or sediment in a covered TMDL jurisdiction.

To be eligible for a grant under this section, an owner or operator referred to in subsection (a) shall submit to the Administrator an application at such time, in such form, and containing such information as the Administrator may require.
The application, at a minimum, shall contain a description of how the amounts of the grant will be used to assist the applicant in meeting a covered TMDL.
Subject to paragraph (2), the Administrator shall award grants to applicants under this section on a competitive basis.
In awarding grants to applicants under this section, the Administrator shall consider—

subparagraph.text: the demonstrated need of the applicant for the grant; and
with respect to the project to be funded using the grant—

clause.text: the effectiveness of any technologies that will be used;
the ecological sensitivity of the geographic area involved; and
whether the use of existing facilities, if any, will be maximized.

paragraph.text: A recipient of a grant under this section shall use the amounts of the grant to implement methods to reduce discharges of nitrogen, phosphorus, and sediment—

subparagraph.text: using proven technology and practices; or
using an innovative practice, subject to a determination by the Administrator that the innovative practice is reasonably expected to reduce the discharges.

subparagraph.header: Engineering or consultation work for water storage projects
subparagraph.text: In the case of a grant made to an owner or operator referred to in subsection (a)(3), amounts of the grant may be used for engineering or consultation work in designing a water storage project if—

clause.text: the project complies with the limitation in paragraph (3); and
the project is completed within 5 years of the date of receipt of the grant.

subparagraph.text: The Administrator shall require repayment of a grant made to carry out a project described in subparagraph (A) if the project is not completed within 5 years of the date of receipt of the grant.

paragraph.text: A recipient of a grant under this section may not use the amounts of the grant—

subparagraph.text: to pay the salary of any individual who is employed by the recipient as of the date of receipt of the grant; or
to pay the salary of any individual hired by the recipient after that date unless—

clause.text: the individual is an expert in the field of reducing discharges from treatment works; and
the recipient can demonstrate, to the satisfaction of the Administrator, that the individual will assist in meeting a covered TMDL.

subsection.text: The Administrator may not make grants under this section to a grant recipient in an amount that exceeds $2,000,000 in a fiscal year.
The Federal share of the cost of a program or activity carried out using amounts from a grant received under this section may not exceed two-thirds of the cost of the program or activity.

paragraph.text:
The Administrator shall prescribe by regulation an increase in the amount of a civil penalty assessed for a violation of the
Federal Water Pollution Control Act (
33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq.
).
The amount of the increase shall be 5 percent of the civil penalty amount determined under that Act for the violation.
The regulations shall apply the increased civil penalty amount only to violations occurring after the date of enactment of this Act.

subsection.header: Establishment of Impaired Waters Improvement Fund

paragraph.text: There is established in the Treasury of the United States a trust fund to be known as the Impaired Waters Improvement Fund.

text.cato:entity: There are hereby appropriated to the Impaired Waters Improvement Fund for each of fiscal years 2015 through 2019 amounts equivalent to amounts received in the Treasury that are attributable to increases in civil penalty amounts assessed pursuant to subsection (a) or $100,000,000, whichever is less.

paragraph.text: Amounts in the Impaired Waters Improvement Fund shall be available, as provided in appropriations Acts, for making expenditures to carry out section 3.
